articles.headline: Monster Energy Drink Cited in Deaths
articles.snippet: Five people may have died after drinking Monster Energy, a popular energy drink that is high in caffeine, according to reports released by the Food and Drug Administration.
articles.abstract: Five people may have died after drinking Monster Energy, a popular energy drink that is high in caffeine, according to reports released by the Food and Drug Administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five people may have died over the past three years after drinking Monster Energy, a popular energy drink that is high in caffeine, according to incident reports recently released by the Food and Drug Administration.

articles.headline: China’s Doldrums Put Pressure on U.S. Exporters
articles.snippet: Job reductions are emerging in industries like mining, heavy machinery and scrap metal that boomed along with China, illustrating the risks to the American economy if growth continues to slow.
articles.abstract: Job reductions are emerging in industries like mining, heavy machinery and scrap metal that boomed along with China, illustrating the risks to the American economy if growth continues to slow.
articles.lead_paragraph: As China’s economy cools, American exporters are increasingly feeling the chill.

articles.headline: Settlement Eases Rules for Some Medicare Patients
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of people with chronic conditions and disabilities may find it easier to qualify for home health care, nursing home stays and outpatient therapy.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of people with chronic conditions and disabilities may find it easier to qualify for home health care, nursing home stays and outpatient therapy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tens of thousands of people with chronic conditions and disabilities may find it easier to qualify for Medicare coverage of potentially costly home health care, skilled nursing home stays and outpatient therapy under policy changes planned by the Obama administration.

articles.headline: Wisconsin Nuclear Reactor to Be Closed
articles.snippet: The power company was unable to find a buyer for the Kewaunee Power Station, which was deemed economically impractical in light of falling demand and the low price of natural gas.
articles.abstract: The power company was unable to find a buyer for the Kewaunee Power Station, which was deemed economically impractical in light of falling demand and the low price of natural gas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The owner of a small nuclear reactor in Wisconsin said Monday that it would close the Kewaunee Power Station  early next year because it was unable to find a buyer and the plant was no longer economically viable.

articles.headline: In Report, Speed Trades’ Problems and Pluses
articles.snippet: A British government study found that the increasing prevalence of computerized trading might lead to isolated incidents of instability in the financial markets.
articles.abstract: A British government study found that the increasing prevalence of computerized trading might lead to isolated incidents of instability in the financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rise of controversial high-speed trading firms has generally been a good thing for ordinary investors, a two-year British government study has concluded. The study, however, found that the increasing prevalence of computerized trading may lead to isolated incidents of instability in the financial markets.

articles.headline: Presidential Election Weighs on the Federal Reserve
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney has promised he would replace Ben Bernanke as Fed chairman. But of his three likely contenders, only one would represent a sharp departure from current policy.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney has promised he would replace Ben Bernanke as Fed chairman. But of his three likely contenders, only one would represent a sharp departure from current policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The next significant event for monetary policy is not the Federal Reserve’s meeting Tuesday and Wednesday, which is likely to pass quietly, but the presidential election two weeks later.

articles.headline: In Mobile World, Tech Giants Scramble to Get Up to Speed
articles.snippet: Companies like Google, Microsoft and Intel are scrambling to reinvent their businesses now that the old model — a customer sitting at a PC — no longer applies.
articles.abstract: Companies like Google, Microsoft and Intel are scrambling to reinvent their businesses now that the old model — a customer sitting at a PC — no longer applies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel made its fortune on the chips that power personal computers, and Microsoft on the software that goes inside. Google’s secret sauce is that it finds what you are looking for on the Internet. But the ground is shifting beneath these tech titans because of a major force: the rise of mobile devices.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Casting Dual Roles, at Treasury and the Fed
articles.snippet: If Mitt Romney wins the presidency, he has already pledged he will replace Ben Bernanke, whose term as Federal Reserve chairman ends in January 2014, in just over 15 months. Mr. Bernanke, however, has told close friends that even if Mr. Obama wins...
articles.abstract: If Mitt Romney wins the presidency, he has already pledged he will replace Ben Bernanke, whose term as Federal Reserve chairman ends in January 2014, in just over 15 months. Mr. Bernanke, however, has told close friends that even if Mr. Obama wins, he probably will not stand for re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last couple of months, there has been a parlor game on Wall Street and in Washington about who will become the next Treasury secretary. After all, Timothy F. Geithner has made it clear he plans to be out of that office at the end of the year whether President Obama is re-elected or not.

articles.headline: Sparring Over Foreign Policy, Obama Goes on the Offense
articles.snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney engaged in a contentious exchange over America’s place in the world as each sought to portray the other as an unreliable commander in chief in a dangerous era.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Mitt Romney engaged in a contentious exchange over America’s place in the world as each sought to portray the other as an unreliable commander in chief in a dangerous era.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — President Obama and Mitt Romney wrapped up a series of defining debates on Monday night with a bristling exchange over America’s place in the world as each sought to portray the other as an unreliable commander in chief in a dangerous era.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Role Reversal Gives President Harder Line, and Punch Lines
articles.snippet: Monday night’s debate provided an odd role reversal that made Mitt Romney seem on the defensive, while President Obama offered sharp responses to criticism of his foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Monday night’s debate provided an odd role reversal that made Mitt Romney seem on the defensive, while President Obama offered sharp responses to criticism of his foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney came in peace. He said he wanted better education, more financial aid, gender equality and rule of law, and he was talking about the Middle East, not the Midwest. He even said he was consulting a group of “Arab scholars” sponsored by, of all things, the United Nations, to shape his plan for fixing the troubled region. “We can’t kill our way out of this mess,” he said.

articles.headline: With Debates Over, Candidates Race to Clinch Vital States
articles.snippet: President Obama began a furious two-week effort to beat back a late surge by Mitt Romney and hang on to battleground states where many voters are already casting ballots.
articles.abstract: President Obama began a furious two-week effort to beat back a late surge by Mitt Romney and hang on to battleground states where many voters are already casting ballots.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — President Obama started making his closing argument for a second term on Tuesday, beginning a furious two-week effort to beat back a late surge by Mitt Romney and hang on to battleground states where voters are already casting ballots in large numbers.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Buon Appetito, but Not Next to the Monuments
articles.snippet: A new ordinance outlaws eating and drinking at historic sites in Rome to better protect the city’s monuments, with fines of up to $650.
articles.abstract: A new ordinance outlaws eating and drinking at historic sites in Rome to better protect the city’s monuments, with fines of up to $650.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Dapper as always in their bleached white shirts and matching caps, members of Rome’s municipal police force were out on the Spanish Steps one warm autumn day, trolling for offenders.
